metadata.document_name: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks
metadata.source_pdf: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf
metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Here are the key legal issues extracted from the document:
• Whether the trade mark COOLPOLY has distinctive character and is capable of distinguishing goods or services of one person from those of another.
• The application of Sections 9(1)(a)1 and 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act to the registration of the mark COOLPOLY.
• Whether the mark COOLPOLY is similar to earlier trade marks already on record for the same or similar goods/services and thus subject to relative grounds of refusal under Section 11 of the Act.
• The requirements for filing a duly stamped TM-48 in trade mark applications.
• Whether the mark COOLPOLY is inherently distinctive or descriptive of the goods for which registration was sought.
• The relevance of secondary meaning to proposed use registrations under the Trade Marks Act.
• Whether the Senior Examiner's findings on the objections raised against the appellant's application were correct and reasonable.
• The proper interpretation and application of Sections 9, 11, and 12 of the Trade Marks Act in this case.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: Ticona Polymers Inc. v. Registrar of Trade Marks**

**Background:**
Ticona Polymers Inc., a company, filed an application (No. 2847019) to register the word mark "COOLPOLY" as a trade mark in two classes: Class 1 for plastic and carbon moulding materials for use in the manufacture of moulded plastic articles, and Class 9 for moulded heat sinks for use in computers and parts and components thereof and moulded electrical conductors. The application was filed on November 19, 2014.

**Legal Issues:**
The issue in this case is whether the word mark "COOLPOLY" meets the requirements for registration as a trade mark under the Trade Marks Act, 1999. Specifically, the company's application was objected to by the Registrar of Trade Marks on the grounds that:

1. The mark is devoid of distinctive character (Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act).
2. The mark is similar or identical to an earlier trade mark and/or services (Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act).

**Arguments:**

* Ticona Polymers Inc. argued that the word mark "COOLPOLY" is distinctive and has been registered in various jurisdictions.
* They also contended that the Senior Examiner's objections under Section 11 were wrong, as the cited marks are visually, phonetically, and conceptually different.

**Court Findings:**
The Hon'ble Mr. Justice C.Hari Shankar of the High Court of Delhi examined the arguments made by both sides and considered the relevant provisions of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. He found that:

* The word mark "COOLPOLY" is a combination of two English words, "cool" and "poly".
* As a whole, the mark "COOLPOLY" is not inherently distinctive; rather, it is descriptive of the goods for which registration was sought.
* Since the application is filed on a "proposed to be used" basis, the mark has not acquired any secondary meaning.

**Decision:**
Based on these findings, the court upheld the impugned order passed by the Senior Examiner in rejecting Ticona Polymers Inc.'s trade mark application. The decision was made under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.

This is to note, however, that this summary is limited and certain points from the given text are not explicitly elaborated up on and few crucial information are not discussed at length.

C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 1 of 8 
 
 
$~2 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
+  
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022 
 
TICONA POLYMERS, INC.  
 
    ..... Appellant 
Through: 
Ms. 
Aamna 
Hasan, 
Mr. 
Vaibhav 
Vutts 
and 
Mr. 
Devadathan 
Jayachandran, Advs. 
 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
REGISTRAR OF TRADE MARKS  
    ..... Respondent 
Through: 
Mr. 
Harish 
Vaidyanathan, 
CGSC with Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr 
Sagar Mehlawat, Mr. Alexander Mathai 
Paikaday, Advs. 
 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE C.HARI SHANKAR 
 
 
 
 
JUDGMENT (ORAL) 
% 
 
 
 
         28.02.2023 
 
1. 
This appeal, under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, 
assails order dated 26th October 2020 passed by the Senior Examiner 
in the office of the Registrar of Trade Marks, whereby Application 
No. 2847019, filed by the appellant for registration of the word mark 
―COOLPOLY‖, in (i) Class 1 in respect of plastic and carbon 
moulding materials for use in the manufacture of moulded plastic 
articles and (ii) Class 9 in respect of moulded heat sinks for use in 
computers and parts and components thereof and moulded electrical 
conductors, was rejected. 
 
2. 
Application No. 2847019 was filed by the appellant on 19th 
November 2014.  Consequent to a preliminary scrutiny, First 
Examination Report (FER) dated 13th January 2016 was issued by the 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 2 of 8 
 
 
Registrar, objecting to the registration of the aforesaid mark 
COOLPOLY under Sections 9(1)(a)1 and 11(1) (though not expressly 
quoted) of the Trade Marks Act.  The objections in the FER read thus: 
 
―1.  The trade marks which are devoid of any distinctive 
character, that is to say, not capable of distinguishing the goods 
or services of one person from those of another person; 
 
2.  
The Trade Mark application is open to objection on 
relative grounds of refusal under Section 11 of the Act because 
the same/similar trade mark(s) is/are already on record of the 
register for the same or similar goods/services.  The detail of 
same/similar trade marks is enclosed herewith  
 
Save as provided in Sec. 12, a trade mark shall not be 
registered if, because of-its identity with an earlier trade mark 
and similarity of goods or services covered by; the trade mark; 
or its similarity to an earlier trade mark and the identity or 
similarity of the goods or services covered by the trade mark,‖ 
 
3. 
 Additionally, the FER required the appellant to file the duly 
stamped TM-48 which, Ms. Aamna Hasan submits, was filed. 
 
4. 
Of the aforesaid two objections raised in the FER, the impugned 
order has dropped the objections predicated on Sections 11 and 12.  
The Senior Examiner proceeds, thereafter, to reject the appellant’s 
application on the ground that  
(i) 
COOLPOLY was merely a combination of the two 
English words COOL and POLY, 
(ii) 
COOLPOLY, as a whole, was not inherently distinctive,  
(iii) the mark was, on the other hand, descriptive of the goods 
in respect of which its registration was sought, and 
                                          
1 9.  
Absolute grounds for refusal of registration. –   
(1)  
The trade marks –  
(a)  
which are devoid of any distinctive character, that is to say, not capable of 
distinguishing the goods or services of one person from those of another person; 
***** 
 
shall not be registered. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 3 of 8 
 
 
(iv) 
as registration was sought on a ―proposed to be used‖ 
basis, it had not acquired any secondary meaning. 
(It is not clear from the impugned order, which is extremely clumsily 
written and worded, whether the Senior Examiner finds COOLPOLY 
as a whole to be descriptive or whether she finds COOL and POLY 
individually to be descriptive.)  
  
5. 
The following passage from the impugned order contains what 
may be called the reasoning of the Senior Examiner: 
 
―Adv. Aamna Hasan appeared and argued and submitted that. 
Goods have no reference to mark, and the mark is registered in 
various jurisdictions so consider as a distinctive. Thirdly sec. 11 
is not applicable, heard, and checked the details of application, it 
appears that, total five opportunities of hearing given. As per 
details on record and submission made by advocate it appears 
that, the cited marks are visually ,phonetically, and conceptually 
different, so obj. u/s 11 waived, moreover obj. u/s 9 is sustain 
because mark as a whole is not inherently distinctive, it is a 
mere combination of an English word "coolpoly" which is not 
distinctive and descriptive to applied goods of "[CLASS-1] 
Plastic and carbon molding materials for use in the manufacture 
of molded plastic articles.[CLASS-9] Molded heat sinks for use 
in computers and parts and components therefore and molded 
electrical conductors." .the mark is mere combination of word 
"cool" and "poly" hence it is not inherently distinctive, so no one 
can claim any exclusive right over the descriptive word, until 
and unless the mark has acquired distinctiveness by long and 
continuous commercial use and Mark is descriptive in nature 
and has direct reference to goods applied, it has describes 
quality and intended purpose, further more it is a proposed to be 
used mark, so not having user so no acquired secondary 
meaning. The adv. Also submitted that, the mark is registered in 
various jurisdiction so consider as distinctive, whereas trans-
border reputation or goodwill is not recognized by the Hon. 
Supreme court in landmark judgment of PRIUS. Furthermore, it 
is a well settled law that, mere combination of two known word 
or abbreviation thereof would not be an invented word, even 
though the combination may not have been in use before, if to 
the eyes or ear the same idea would be conveyed as by the 
words in its ordinary form, as decided in the cases of "E. 
                                                                                                                   
Provided that a trade mark shall not be refused registration if before the date of 
application for registration it has acquired a distinctive character as a result of the use made of it or 
is a well-known trade mark. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 4 of 8 
 
 
Griffiths Hughes Ltd. vs Vick Chemical Co. AND A.R. Khaleel 
And Sons vs Registrar of Trade Marks In India", so upon 
considering the material on record, and submission made by the 
advocate, the applicant and adv. is fail to prove the justification 
for waving off obj. raised under sec.9 (1)(a) trade Mark Act 
1999.‖ 
 
6. 
Aggrieved, the appellant has appealed to this Court. 
 
7. 
I have heard Ms. Aamna Hasan, learned Counsel for the 
appellant and Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan, learned Counsel for the 
respondent. 
 
8. 
None of the considerations on which the Senior Examiner has 
rejected the appellant’s application commend themselves to 
acceptance. 
 
9. 
In the first place, the learned Senior Examiner was required to 
examine the entitlement to registration, of the COOLPOLY mark as a 
whole, and not by breaking it into COOL and POLY.   
 
10. 
The Senior Examiner has, in rejecting the appellant’s 
application for registration of the COOLPOLY mark, proceeded on 
the reasoning that COOLPOLY was a mere portmanteau of the words 
COOL and POLY, each of which was descriptive of the nature of the 
goods in respect of which registration of the mark was sought.  As 
such, the Senior Examiner holds that the mark was not inherently 
distinctive as required by Section 9(1)(a) of the Trademarks Act. 
 
11. 
 It is well settled that a mark cannot be dissected into its 
individual parts while examining its entitlement to registration.  
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 5 of 8 
 
 
Though Section 17(1)2 of the Trademarks Act statutory embodies this 
anti-dissection principle in the context of infringement proceedings, 
the principle would apply, mutatis mutandis, even at the stage when 
the mark is examined for its entitlement for registration as it is only 
the factum of registration which brings, in its wake, the privileges that 
follow, including protection against infringement.  
 
12. 
Seen as a whole, it cannot be said that the word COOLPOLY 
has any etymological meaning or significance in the English language.  
It is not a word of common – or, for that manner, even uncommon – 
usage, as would render it incapable of distinguishing goods of one 
person from those of another if used as a trade mark.  Indeed, the 
impugned order is silent as to why the mark is not distinctive.  Rather, 
the Senior Examiner appears to have, clearly erroneously, conflated 
the concept of lack of distinctiveness, addressed by Section 9(1)(a), 
and descriptiveness, addressed by Section 9(1)(b), and confused the 
two.   
 
13. 
Section 9(1)(a) would apply only where a mark was so common 
and so lacking in distinction as would make it impossible, on the basis 
of that mark, to distinguish between the goods of one person and 
goods of another. Common English words and phrases of everyday 
usage would fall within this category.  Such common English words 
cannot be registered as marks, unless they enjoy the benefit of the 
                                          
2 17.  
Effect of registration of parts of a mark. –  
(1)  
When a trade mark consists of several matters, its registration shall confer on the 
proprietor exclusive right to the use of the trade mark taken as a whole. 
(2)  
Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), when a trade mark— 
(a)  
contains any part –  
(i)  
which is not the subject of a separate application by the proprietor for 
registration as a trade mark; or 
(ii)  
which is not separately registered by the proprietor as a trade mark; or 
(b)  
contains any matter which is common to the trade or is otherwise of a non-
distinctive character, 
the registration thereof shall not confer any exclusive right in the matter forming only a part of the 
whole of the trade mark so registered. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 6 of 8 
 
 
proviso to Section 9(1), which would apply where the mark, before the 
date of registration, has acquired distinctiveness –in trade mark 
terminology, a ―secondary meaning‖ –  by dint of long or continuous 
use, or is a ―well known trade mark‖ within the meaning of Section 
2(1)(zg)3 of the Trade Marks Act.    
 
14. 
The impugned order does not hold that COOLPOLY is a word 
of common English usage.  Indeed, as already noted, COOLPOLY has 
no meaning.  The impugned order does not cite any other mark of any 
other person, similar to ―COOLPOLY‖ or provide any reason as to 
why the use of the mark ―COOLPOLY‖ in respect of goods for which 
registration was sought by the appellant would make it impossible to 
distinguish between the said goods or any other goods available in the 
market. 
 
15. 
Adverting, next, to the aspect of descriptiveness, COOLPOLY, 
being a word with no meaning, can obviously not be regarded as 
descriptive of the goods in respect of which registration was sought by 
the appellant.  For that matter, it cannot be said that either of the parts 
of the mark ―COOL‖ or ―POLY‖, even seen individually, is 
descriptive of the nature of the goods in respect of which registration 
was sought.  Registration of the mark ―COOLPOLY‖ was sought in 
respect of plastic and carbon moulding materials used in the 
manufacture of moulded plastic articles and moulded heat sinks for 
use in computers and parts and components thereof and moulded 
electrical conductors.  The impugned order is silent as to how the 
words ―COOL‖ and ―POLY‖ even if seen individually, are descriptive 
                                          
3 (zg)  
―well-known trade mark‖, in relation to any goods or services, means a mark which has become so 
to the substantial segment of the public which uses such goods or receives such services that the use of such 
mark in relation to other goods or services would be likely to be taken as indicating a connection in the course 
of trade or rendering of services between those goods or services and a person during the mark in relation to 
the first-mentioned goods or services. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 7 of 8 
 
 
of the products in respect of which registration was sought or were 
wanting any distinctive character. 
 
16. 
The basic prerequisites of Section 9(1)(a) do not appear to be 
addressed in the impugned order.  In a sense, the impugned order is 
unreasoned, as it merely holds, as the mere ipse dixit of the Senior 
Examiner, that the expression ―COOL‖ and ―POLY‖ were descriptive 
of the products in respect of which registration was sought.   
 
17. 
This Court is not inclined to agree with the said reasoning or 
conclusion.  In the opinion of the Court, 
(i) 
COOLPOLY cannot, for examining distinctiveness, be 
vivisected into COOL and POLY, 
(ii) 
COOLPOLY is not a word of common English usage, 
(iii) COOLPOLY, if used as a mark by one person is, 
therefore, perfectly capable of distinguishing the goods or 
services of that person, in respect of which the mark is used, 
from the goods and services of others, 
(iv) 
the proscription against registration contained in Section 
9(1)(a) would not, therefore, apply, 
(v) 
neither COOLPOLY, nor COOL and POLY individually 
seen, are descriptive of the goods in respect of which the 
appellant sought registration of the COOLPOLY mark and 
(vi) 
the proscription against registration contained in Section 
9(1)(b) would also, therefore, not apply. 
 
18. 
As such, the impugned order, which is unsustainable in law or 
on facts, is quashed and set aside.   
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 8 of 8 
 
 
19. 
As the application of the appellant has yet to be advertised, the 
application is remanded to the Registrar to advertise the mark and 
proceed thereafter in accordance with the provisions of the 
Trademarks Act and the Trademarks Rule.   
 
20. 
The appeal stands allowed accordingly with no orders as to 
costs. 
 
21. 
Ms. Hasan prays that a direction for a time bound decision may 
be passed.  This Court is hesitant to do so as this Court is not aware of 
the amount of work which is pending before the Registrar.  However, 
Mr. Vaidyanathan very fairly undertakes to ensure that there would be 
no delay in the matter.   
 
22. 
Let this order be uploaded on the website of this Court within 
24 hours. 
 
 
 
 
C.HARI SHANKAR, J 
FEBRUARY 28, 2023  
rb 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary:**

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard an appeal (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022) filed by Ticona Polymers, Inc., against the Registrar of Trade Marks.

**Background:**
Ticona Polymers, Inc. applied for registration of the word mark "COOLPOLY" in two classes (1 and 9) on November 19, 2014. The application was objected to under Sections 9(1)(a)1 and 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act.

**Arguments:**

*   Appellant's Arguments: Ms. Aamna Hasan argued that the objections were dropped, leaving only the objection that "COOLPOLY" was devoid of distinctive character.
*   Respondent's Arguments: The Junior Counsel for the Registrar contended that "COOLPOLY" was inherently descriptive and did not qualify for registration.

**Court Decision:**

The Hon'ble Mr. Justice C.Hari Shankar issued his oral judgment on February 28, 2023, rejecting the appellant's application under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act.

**Points of Law Mentioned:**

*   Sections 9(1)(a) and 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act
*   Absolute grounds for refusal of registration (Section 9) - lack of distinctive character

[Source](https://www.litigationguru.com/lawcase/20230301/202302281441.pdf): Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks (PDF: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)

**Case Details**

* Case number: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001489

**Parties**

* Appellant: Ticona Polymers, Inc.
	+ Represented by: Ms. Aamna Hasan, Mr. Vaibhav Vutts, and Mr. Devadathan Jayachandran
* Respondent: Registrar of Trade Marks
	+ Represented by: Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan, CGSC with Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. Sagar Mehlawat, and Mr. Alexander Mathai Paikaday

**Background**

* Application No. 2847019 was filed by Ticona Polymers, Inc. on November 19, 2014.
* The application sought registration of the word mark "COOLPOLY" in Class 1 and Class 9.

**Proceedings**

* A preliminary scrutiny led to a First Examination Report dated January 13, 2016.
* This appeal under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act, challenges an order dated October 26, 2020 rejecting Registration No. 2847019.

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary:
Source: PDF document "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf"

**Summary**

The case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022 pertains to Ticona Polymers' application for trademark registration under the trade mark COOLPOLY.

**Key Facts and Proceedings:**

* The Registrar objected to the registration under Sections 9(1)(a) and 11 of the Trade Marks Act.
* The objections included:
	+ Devoid of distinctive character (Section 9(1)(a))
	+ Relative grounds of refusal due to identical or similar trade marks already registered (Section 11)
	+ Failure to file a duly stamped TM-48
* The Senior Examiner dropped Section 11 and 12 objections, but rejected the application under Sections 9(1)(a)  for reasons:
	+ COOLPOLY was not inherently distinctive
	+ It was descriptive of the goods in question

**Dates, Names, and Amounts:**

* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001489
* Date of signing: March 1, 2023

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks**

**Case Number:** C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
**Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/001489

**Background:**
The appeal is filed by Ticona Polymers, Inc. against the decision of the Registrar of Trade Marks rejecting their application for registration of the mark "COOLPOLY" under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.

**Facts:**

* The applicant sought to register the mark "COOLPOLY" as a proposed to be used trade mark.
* The Senior Examiner rejected the application on grounds that the mark is not inherently distinctive and is descriptive of the applied goods (plastic and carbon molding materials).
* The Senior Examiner found that the combination of words "cool" and "poly" does not create a distinctive word, but rather a descriptive phrase that conveys an idea related to the goods.

**Arguments:**

* The applicant argued that the mark has been registered in various jurisdictions, making it considered distinctive.
* The applicant also submitted that trans-border reputation or goodwill is not recognized by the Hon. Supreme Court in landmark judgments.
* The applicant further argued that a mere combination of two known words does not constitute an invented word.

**Decision:**
The learned Counsel for the appellant argued that none of the considerations on which the Senior Examiner rejected the application commend themselves to acceptance. The court agreed with this argument and concluded that the Senior Examiner should have examined the entitlement to registration as a whole, rather than breaking the mark into "COOL" and "POLY".

**Outcome:**
The appeal is admitted and requires further consideration by the Court.

Source:
Section 42 of Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks, PDF document (2023/DHC/001489)
tree_structure.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 3 from the provided PDF:

**Case details:** Ticona Polymers, Inc. vs Registrar of Trade Marks (2022)

**Content:**

The Senior Examiner's reasoning for rejecting the registration of "COOLPOLY" as a trade mark is that it is not inherently distinctive and is a mere combination of descriptive words "cool" and "poly". The examiner states that the mark has no acquired secondary meaning since it was sought to be registered on a proposed-to-be-used basis. The Examiner also finds that the mark is descriptive in nature, referring directly to the goods applied for manufacture.

**Key arguments:**

* Appellant (Ticona Polymers) argued that the mark is visually, phonetically, and conceptually different from cited marks and therefore should not be rejected under Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act.
* The Senior Examiner did not waive objections under Section 9, as "COOLPOLY" is a descriptive word combination that lacks inherent distinctiveness.

**Source:** 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks (2023/DHC/001489) - PDF source is provided in the initial query.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 3 of 8 
 
 
(iv) 
as registration was sought on a ―proposed to be used‖ 
basis, it had not acquired any secondary meaning. 
(It is not clear from the impugned order, which is extremely clumsily 
written and worded, whether the Senior Examiner finds COOLPOLY 
as a whole to be descriptive or whether she finds COOL and POLY 
individually to be descriptive.)  
  
5. 
The following passage from the impugned order contains what 
may be called the reasoning of the Senior Examiner: 
 
―Adv. Aamna Hasan appeared and argued and submitted that. 
Goods have no reference to mark, and the mark is registered in 
various jurisdictions so consider as a distinctive. Thirdly sec. 11 
is not applicable, heard, and checked the details of application, it 
appears that, total five opportunities of hearing given. As per 
details on record and submission made by advocate it appears 
that, the cited marks are visually ,phonetically, and conceptually 
different, so obj. u/s 11 waived, moreover obj. u/s 9 is sustain 
because mark as a whole is not inherently distinctive, it is a 
mere combination of an English word "coolpoly" which is not 
distinctive and descriptive to applied goods of "[CLASS-1] 
Plastic and carbon molding materials for use in the manufacture 
of molded plastic articles.[CLASS-9] Molded heat sinks for use 
in computers and parts and components therefore and molded 
electrical conductors." .the mark is mere combination of word 
"cool" and "poly" hence it is not inherently distinctive, so no one 
can claim any exclusive right over the descriptive word, until 
and unless the mark has acquired distinctiveness by long and 
continuous commercial use and Mark is descriptive in nature 
and has direct reference to goods applied, it has describes 
quality and intended purpose, further more it is a proposed to be 
used mark, so not having user so no acquired secondary 
meaning. The adv. Also submitted that, the mark is registered in 
various jurisdiction so consider as distinctive, whereas trans-
border reputation or goodwill is not recognized by the Hon. 
Supreme court in landmark judgment of PRIUS. Furthermore, it 
is a well settled law that, mere combination of two known word 
or abbreviation thereof would not be an invented word, even 
though the combination may not have been in use before, if to 
the eyes or ear the same idea would be conveyed as by the 
words in its ordinary form, as decided in the cases of "E. 
                                                                                                                   
Provided that a trade mark shall not be refused registration if before the date of 
application for registration it has acquired a distinctive character as a result of the use made of it or 
is a well-known trade mark. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 4 of the PDF:

**Case Overview**

* Case Name: Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001489
* C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022

**Background**

* The applicant, Ticona Polymers, had filed an application for registration of the mark "COOLPOLY"
* The Senior Examiner rejected the application on grounds that "COOL" and "POLY" are descriptive words and therefore, the mark is not inherently distinctive

**Proceedings**

* Griffiths Hughes Ltd. vs Vick Chemical Co. AND A.R. Khaleel & Sons was cited as a precedent in this case
* The Senior Examiner's decision to dissect the COOLPOLY mark into its individual parts (COOL and POLY) was criticized by the Counsel for the appellant, who argued that the mark should be examined as a whole

**Judgment**

* The Court held that the senior examiner erred in rejecting the application based on the reasoning that "COOL" and "POLY" are descriptive words.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 4 of 8 
 
 
Griffiths Hughes Ltd. vs Vick Chemical Co. AND A.R. Khaleel 
And Sons vs Registrar of Trade Marks In India", so upon 
considering the material on record, and submission made by the 
advocate, the applicant and adv. is fail to prove the justification 
for waving off obj. raised under sec.9 (1)(a) trade Mark Act 
1999.‖ 
 
6. 
Aggrieved, the appellant has appealed to this Court. 
 
7. 
I have heard Ms. Aamna Hasan, learned Counsel for the 
appellant and Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan, learned Counsel for the 
respondent. 
 
8. 
None of the considerations on which the Senior Examiner has 
rejected the appellant’s application commend themselves to 
acceptance. 
 
9. 
In the first place, the learned Senior Examiner was required to 
examine the entitlement to registration, of the COOLPOLY mark as a 
whole, and not by breaking it into COOL and POLY.   
 
10. 
The Senior Examiner has, in rejecting the appellant’s 
application for registration of the COOLPOLY mark, proceeded on 
the reasoning that COOLPOLY was a mere portmanteau of the words 
COOL and POLY, each of which was descriptive of the nature of the 
goods in respect of which registration of the mark was sought.  As 
such, the Senior Examiner holds that the mark was not inherently 
distinctive as required by Section 9(1)(a) of the Trademarks Act. 
 
11. 
 It is well settled that a mark cannot be dissected into its 
individual parts while examining its entitlement to registration.  
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary: Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks**

**Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/001489
**C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022**

This is a case between Ticona Polymers, Inc. (Appellant) and the Registrar of Trade Marks (Respondent) heard in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi.

**Facts and Arguments:**

The Appellant sought registration for the mark "COOLPOLY" in respect of plastic and carbon moulding materials used in various industries. The Respondent refused registration, citing lack of distinctiveness under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trademarks Act. However, the impugned order is silent on why the mark is not distinctive.

**Legal Arguments:**

* The Appellant argues that although Section 17(1)2 embodies an anti-dissection principle in infringement proceedings, it applies mutatis mutandis to the examination of marks for registration.
* The Appellant claims that "COOLPOLY" has no etymological meaning or significance in the English language and is not a word of common usage, making it distinctive.
* The Respondent's impugned order confused lack of distinctiveness under Section 9(1)(a) with descriptiveness under Section 9(1)(b).

**Decisions:**

The court decision is not provided in this extract.

**PDF Source:** Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks, Case No.: 2023/DHC/001489 (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022)

Please note that this summary is based on the extracted section from page 5-6 of the PDF document and may not reflect the full scope or outcome of the case.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 5 from the PDF:

**Court Case:** Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022)

**Legal Facts:**

* The case involves an appeal against a decision by the Senior Examiner regarding the registration of the mark "COOLPOLY".
* Section 17(1)(2) of the Trademarks Act embodies the anti-dissection principle in infringement proceedings, which applies even at the stage of examining entitlement for registration.
* Section 9(1)(a) addresses lack of distinctiveness and Section 9(1)(b) addresses descriptiveness.

**Arguments:**

* The word "COOLPOLY" has no etymological meaning or significance in the English language, making it incapable of distinguishing goods of one person from those of another if used as a trade mark.
* The Senior Examiner incorrectly conflated lack of distinctiveness and descriptiveness.

The PDF source is: `42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf` (Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489).
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 5 of 8 
 
 
Though Section 17(1)2 of the Trademarks Act statutory embodies this 
anti-dissection principle in the context of infringement proceedings, 
the principle would apply, mutatis mutandis, even at the stage when 
the mark is examined for its entitlement for registration as it is only 
the factum of registration which brings, in its wake, the privileges that 
follow, including protection against infringement.  
 
12. 
Seen as a whole, it cannot be said that the word COOLPOLY 
has any etymological meaning or significance in the English language.  
It is not a word of common – or, for that manner, even uncommon – 
usage, as would render it incapable of distinguishing goods of one 
person from those of another if used as a trade mark.  Indeed, the 
impugned order is silent as to why the mark is not distinctive.  Rather, 
the Senior Examiner appears to have, clearly erroneously, conflated 
the concept of lack of distinctiveness, addressed by Section 9(1)(a), 
and descriptiveness, addressed by Section 9(1)(b), and confused the 
two.   
 
13. 
Section 9(1)(a) would apply only where a mark was so common 
and so lacking in distinction as would make it impossible, on the basis 
of that mark, to distinguish between the goods of one person and 
goods of another. Common English words and phrases of everyday 
usage would fall within this category.  Such common English words 
cannot be registered as marks, unless they enjoy the benefit of the 
                                          
2 17.  
Effect of registration of parts of a mark. –  
(1)  
When a trade mark consists of several matters, its registration shall confer on the 
proprietor exclusive right to the use of the trade mark taken as a whole. 
(2)  
Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), when a trade mark— 
(a)  
contains any part –  
(i)  
which is not the subject of a separate application by the proprietor for 
registration as a trade mark; or 
(ii)  
which is not separately registered by the proprietor as a trade mark; or 
(b)  
contains any matter which is common to the trade or is otherwise of a non-
distinctive character, 
the registration thereof shall not confer any exclusive right in the matter forming only a part of the 
whole of the trade mark so registered. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 6 from the PDF "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf":

The court considers the impugned order's reasoning for rejecting registration of the mark "COOLPOLY" in respect of plastic and carbon moulding materials. The order does not hold that COOLPOLY is a word of common English usage, nor does it cite any similar marks or provide reasons why the use of the mark would cause confusion.

Regarding descriptiveness, the court notes that COOLPOLY has no meaning, making it impossible to be regarded as descriptive of the goods in question. The words "COOL" and "POLY" individually also do not describe the nature of the goods. The impugned order fails to explain how these words could be considered descriptive.

Source: PDF document "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf"

Court case details:
* Case No.: 2023/DHC/001489
* C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022
* Appellant: Ticona Polymers, Inc.
* Respondent: Registrar of Trade Marks
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 6 of 8 
 
 
proviso to Section 9(1), which would apply where the mark, before the 
date of registration, has acquired distinctiveness –in trade mark 
terminology, a ―secondary meaning‖ –  by dint of long or continuous 
use, or is a ―well known trade mark‖ within the meaning of Section 
2(1)(zg)3 of the Trade Marks Act.    
 
14. 
The impugned order does not hold that COOLPOLY is a word 
of common English usage.  Indeed, as already noted, COOLPOLY has 
no meaning.  The impugned order does not cite any other mark of any 
other person, similar to ―COOLPOLY‖ or provide any reason as to 
why the use of the mark ―COOLPOLY‖ in respect of goods for which 
registration was sought by the appellant would make it impossible to 
distinguish between the said goods or any other goods available in the 
market. 
 
15. 
Adverting, next, to the aspect of descriptiveness, COOLPOLY, 
being a word with no meaning, can obviously not be regarded as 
descriptive of the goods in respect of which registration was sought by 
the appellant.  For that matter, it cannot be said that either of the parts 
of the mark ―COOL‖ or ―POLY‖, even seen individually, is 
descriptive of the nature of the goods in respect of which registration 
was sought.  Registration of the mark ―COOLPOLY‖ was sought in 
respect of plastic and carbon moulding materials used in the 
manufacture of moulded plastic articles and moulded heat sinks for 
use in computers and parts and components thereof and moulded 
electrical conductors.  The impugned order is silent as to how the 
words ―COOL‖ and ―POLY‖ even if seen individually, are descriptive 
                                          
3 (zg)  
―well-known trade mark‖, in relation to any goods or services, means a mark which has become so 
to the substantial segment of the public which uses such goods or receives such services that the use of such 
mark in relation to other goods or services would be likely to be taken as indicating a connection in the course 
of trade or rendering of services between those goods or services and a person during the mark in relation to 
the first-mentioned goods or services. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
PDF source: Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf (2023/DHC/001489 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022)

**Case Details**

* Case Number: 2023/DHC/001489
* Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
* Date: February 28, 2023

**Parties**

* Appellant (Ticona Polymers, Inc.): represented by Ms. Aamna Hasan, Mr. Vaibhav Vutts, and Mr. Devadathan Jayachandran, Advs.
* Respondent (Registrar of Trade Marks): represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan, CGSC with Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. Sagar Mehlawat, and Mr. Alexander Mathew

**Case Summary**

Ticona Polymers, Inc. appealed against the rejection of their trademark application for "COOLPOLY" by the Registrar of Trade Marks under Section 9(1)(a) and (b) of the Trademarks Act.

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi held that:

* The impugned order was unreasoned and unsustainable in law or on facts.
* COOLPOLY cannot be vivisected into COOL and POLY for examining distinctiveness.
* COOLPOLY is not a word of common English usage and can distinguish the goods or services of one person from others.
* The proscription against registration contained in Section 9(1)(a) and (b) does not apply to COOLPOLY.
* The impugned order was quarshed and set aside.

**Decision**

The appeal was allowed, and the application of Ticona Polymers, Inc. was remanded to the Registrar for advertisement and further proceedings in accordance with the Trademarks Act and Rule. No orders were passed as to costs.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 7 from the provided PDF (Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks):

**Case Details:** C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022
**Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/001489

**Arguments:**

* The High Court disapproves of the reasoning in the impugned order (page not specified), which stated that "COOL" and "POLY" are descriptive of the products for registration purposes due to an examiner's ipse dixit.
* The court disagrees with this conclusion, stating:
	+ COOLPOLY cannot be vivisected into its individual components (COOL and POLY) for distinctiveness examination.
	+ COOLPOLY is not a common English word in usage.
	+ COOLPOLY can distinguish the goods or services of one person from another's when used as a mark.

**Decision:**

* The impugned order is unsustainable on facts and law.
* Quashed and set aside due to incorrect application of Section 9(1)(a) and (b).

**Author:** SUNIL SINGH NEGI, digitally signed and dated March 1, 2023.

Source: [PDF provided - Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks](42.%%20Ticona%20Polymers%20v.%20Registrar%20of%20Trade%20Marks
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 7 of 8 
 
 
of the products in respect of which registration was sought or were 
wanting any distinctive character. 
 
16. 
The basic prerequisites of Section 9(1)(a) do not appear to be 
addressed in the impugned order.  In a sense, the impugned order is 
unreasoned, as it merely holds, as the mere ipse dixit of the Senior 
Examiner, that the expression ―COOL‖ and ―POLY‖ were descriptive 
of the products in respect of which registration was sought.   
 
17. 
This Court is not inclined to agree with the said reasoning or 
conclusion.  In the opinion of the Court, 
(i) 
COOLPOLY cannot, for examining distinctiveness, be 
vivisected into COOL and POLY, 
(ii) 
COOLPOLY is not a word of common English usage, 
(iii) COOLPOLY, if used as a mark by one person is, 
therefore, perfectly capable of distinguishing the goods or 
services of that person, in respect of which the mark is used, 
from the goods and services of others, 
(iv) 
the proscription against registration contained in Section 
9(1)(a) would not, therefore, apply, 
(v) 
neither COOLPOLY, nor COOL and POLY individually 
seen, are descriptive of the goods in respect of which the 
appellant sought registration of the COOLPOLY mark and 
(vi) 
the proscription against registration contained in Section 
9(1)(b) would also, therefore, not apply. 
 
18. 
As such, the impugned order, which is unsustainable in law or 
on facts, is quashed and set aside.   
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary:
Based on page 8 of the PDF: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf (Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489), here is a summary:

**Case Proceedings**

* The court remands the application of the appellant to the Registrar to advertise the mark and proceed with further proceedings under the Trademarks Act and Rules.
* The appeal is allowed, and no orders are made as to costs.

**Order and Undertaking**

* The lawyer for the respondent (Mr. Vaidyanathan) undertakes to ensure that there would be no delay in the matter.
* The court declines a request from Ms. Hasan for a direction for a time-bound decision due to uncertainty about workloads before the Registrar.

**Dates and Names**

* Date of Judgment: February 28, 2023
* Judge's Name: C.HARI SHANKAR, J

**PDF Source**: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf (Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 8 of 8 
 
 
19. 
As the application of the appellant has yet to be advertised, the 
application is remanded to the Registrar to advertise the mark and 
proceed thereafter in accordance with the provisions of the 
Trademarks Act and the Trademarks Rule.   
 
20. 
The appeal stands allowed accordingly with no orders as to 
costs. 
 
21. 
Ms. Hasan prays that a direction for a time bound decision may 
be passed.  This Court is hesitant to do so as this Court is not aware of 
the amount of work which is pending before the Registrar.  However, 
Mr. Vaidyanathan very fairly undertakes to ensure that there would be 
no delay in the matter.   
 
22. 
Let this order be uploaded on the website of this Court within 
24 hours. 
 
 
 
 
C.HARI SHANKAR, J 
FEBRUARY 28, 2023
